articles.headline: Should You Buy Now, Pay Later? Tread Carefully.
articles.snippet: Afterpay, Apple and other financial tech companies are popularizing installment plans for paying off shopping splurges. These programs can also cause confusion and a loss of control.
articles.abstract: Afterpay, Apple and other financial tech companies are popularizing installment plans for paying off shopping splurges. These programs can also cause confusion and a loss of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Devastating Afghanistan Earthquake Leaves More Than 1,000 Dead
articles.snippet: The quake — the deadliest in the country in two decades — was the latest in a string of tragedies to affect the country since the Taliban seized power from the U.S.-backed government last summer.
articles.abstract: The quake — the deadliest in the country in two decades — was the latest in a string of tragedies to affect the country since the Taliban seized power from the U.S.-backed government last summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For much of the past two decades, the southeastern part of Afghanistan near the Pakistani border was plagued by insurgent activity, as police and military posts were frequently overwhelmed by Taliban fighters, and received few benefits from the American military presence.
articles.byline: By Safiullah Padshah, Alissa J. Rubin and Mike Ives

articles.headline: Gun Bill’s Progress Reflects Political Shift, but G.O.P. Support Is Fragile
articles.snippet: Only two of the 14 Republicans who broke ranks to support taking up gun legislation are facing voters this year, showing how difficult such deals could be in the future.
articles.abstract: Only two of the 14 Republicans who broke ranks to support taking up gun legislation are facing voters this year, showing how difficult such deals could be in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Senate vote on the bipartisan gun control bill.

articles.headline: A Year Later, Some Republicans Second-Guess Boycotting the Jan. 6 Panel
articles.snippet: The decision by Representative Kevin McCarthy not to appoint Republicans to the committee has given Democrats the chance to set out an uninterrupted narrative.
articles.abstract: The decision by Representative Kevin McCarthy not to appoint Republicans to the committee has given Democrats the chance to set out an uninterrupted narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

articles.headline: Russia Crimps Gas Flows Just as Europe Races to Stock Up for Winter
articles.snippet: The routine summer practice of filling Europe’s natural gas tanks has become a battle after Russia cut deliveries by more than half.
articles.abstract: The routine summer practice of filling Europe’s natural gas tanks has become a battle after Russia cut deliveries by more than half.
articles.lead_paragraph: Germany’s largest storage chamber for natural gas stretches underneath a swath of farmland the size of nine soccer fields in the western part of the country. The bucolic area has become a kind of battlefield in Europe’s effort to defend itself against a looming gas crisis driven by Russia.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Jan. 6 Panel Outlines Trump’s Bid to Coerce Justice Dept. Officials
articles.snippet: The committee’s fifth hearing this month vividly depicted a department that worked frantically to stave off a constitutional crisis under pressure from the president.
articles.abstract: The committee’s fifth hearing this month vividly depicted a department that worked frantically to stave off a constitutional crisis under pressure from the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol painted a vivid picture on Thursday of how former President Donald J. Trump directed a wide-ranging bid to strong-arm the Justice Department into overturning the 2020 election, the most brazen attempt by a sitting president since Watergate to manipulate the nation’s law enforcement apparatus to keep himself in power.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Katie Benner

articles.headline: As Midterms Loom, Elections Are No Longer Top Priority for Meta C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg, who once said securing elections was “the most important thing,” has shifted Meta’s focus to the metaverse. That may have real-world implications.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, who once said securing elections was “the most important thing,” has shifted Meta’s focus to the metaverse. That may have real-world implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, made securing the 2020 U.S. election a top priority. He met regularly with an election team, which included more than 300 people from across his company, to prevent misinformation from spreading on the social network. He asked civil rights leaders for advice on upholding voter rights.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: ‘We are in a gas crisis.’ Germany raises emergency level.
articles.snippet: Germany’s economy minister triggered the second stage of a contingency plan a week after Russia cut back on gas to Europe, sending prices soaring and raising fears of shortages.
articles.abstract: Germany’s economy minister triggered the second stage of a contingency plan a week after Russia cut back on gas to Europe, sending prices soaring and raising fears of shortages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Germany warned residents and businesses on Thursday that the country was in a natural gas crisis that could worsen in coming months.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down New York Law Limiting Guns in Public
articles.snippet: The decision, based on a broad interpretation of the Second Amendment, will make it harder for states and localities to restrict guns outside the home.
articles.abstract: The decision, based on a broad interpretation of the Second Amendment, will make it harder for states and localities to restrict guns outside the home.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that Americans have a broad right to arm themselves in public, striking down a New York law that placed strict limits on carrying guns outside the home and setting off a scramble in other states that have similar restrictions.

articles.headline: One Button Could Have ‘Saved More Lives’ in Florida Condo Collapse
articles.snippet: Seven minutes elapsed between the initial rumblings and the collapse of Champlain Towers South in Surfside. But a security guard didn’t know how to activate the building’s warning system.
articles.abstract: Seven minutes elapsed between the initial rumblings and the collapse of Champlain Towers South in Surfside. But a security guard didn’t know how to activate the building’s warning system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURFSIDE, Fla. — The thunderous bang that jolted Jonah Handler and his mother in the middle of the night last June was followed by silence.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Government to Cancel $6 Billion in Student Loans for Defrauded Borrowers
articles.snippet: Around 200,000 who sought relief after attending schools that the Education Department said showed signs of “substantial misconduct” will have their federal student loans wiped out.
articles.abstract: Around 200,000 who sought relief after attending schools that the Education Department said showed signs of “substantial misconduct” will have their federal student loans wiped out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around 200,000 former students who attended schools that they said had defrauded them will have $6 billion in federal loans canceled under a sweeping settlement announced on Wednesday, the latest move by the Biden administration to address the student loan crisis by eliminating some debts.
